section.title: Short-Run Behavior of Rational Functions
section.subsection:
Vertical Asymptotes and Holes
We have previously seen that a polynomial function is defined for all values of x, and its graph is a smooth curve without any breaks or holes. The graph of a rational function, on the other hand, will have breaks or holes at those x-values where it is undefined.
Investigate the graph of f(x) = \displaystyle{\frac{2}{(x - 3)^2}} near x = 3.
This function is undefined for x = 3, so there is no point on the graph with x-coordinate 3. However, we can make a table of values for other values of x. Plotting the ordered pairs in the table results in the points shown in .

Next, we make a table showing x-values close to 3, as in a. As we choose x-values closer and closer to 3, (x - 3)^2 gets closer to 0, so the fraction \dfrac{2}{(x-3)^2} gets very large. This means that the graph approaches, but never touches, the vertical line x=3. In other words, the graph has a vertical asymptote at x=3. We indicate the vertical asymptote by a dashed line, as shown in b. table of values and graph of rational function
The vertical line x=3 in the example above is an example of a vertical asymptote. In general, we have the following result.
However, if both the numerator and denominator of the rational function share a root, we no longer call this a vertical asymptote.
If P(a) and Q(a) are both zero in the rational function f(x)=\frac{P(x)}{Q(x)}, but the reduced expression for f(x) is defined at x=a, then the graph of f(x) has a hole at x=a rather than an asymptote.
Find the vertical asymptotes of G(x) = \displaystyle{\frac{4x^2}{x^2 - 4}}.
To find the vertical asyptotes, we are looking for values of a such that 4a^2 \neq 0 and a^2-4=0. The equation a^2-4=0 has solutions a=2,-2, and both 4(\alert{2})^2\neq0 and 4(\alert{-2})^2\neq0. This means that there are two vertical asymptotes, namely x=2 and x=-2.
Near a vertical asymptote, the graph of a rational function has one of the four characteristic shapes, illustrated in . Locating the vertical asymptotes can help us make a quick sketch of a rational function.
4 cases of behavior near vertical asymptote
Locate the vertical asymptotes and sketch the graph of g(x) = \displaystyle{\frac{x}{x + 1}}.
The denominator, x+1, equals zero when x = -1. Because the numerator does not equal zero when x = -1, there is a vertical asymptote at x = -1. The asymptote separates the graph into two pieces.
We can use the Table feature of a calculator to evaluate g(x) for several values of x on either side of the asymptote, as shown in a. We plot the points found in this way; then connect the points on either side of the asymptote to obtain the graph shown in b.
